title: Ticket #653: Detect operating system, distribution, and version
description:
We would benefit from having code that detects the operating system, distribution, and version. The dependent tickets below require such functionality to exist.

Random notes:

  • Detection on Windows is probably just GetVersionEx.
  • Detection on Linux probably involves grovelling around on disk, looking at things like /etc/redhat-release, /etc/SuSE-release, /etc/issue (unreliable, but maybe a good fallback), and more. Novel on detecting distribution, a longer list of distribution specific files

Proposed development order:

  1. Create new subdirectory for this work. condor_osdetect, perhaps.
  2. Create simple command line program that reports the detected OS. At first it won't do anything useful. It should link in various Condor libraries, notably c++_util, since we will likely eventually need safe_open_wrapper and the like. Also set up the Imake/autoconf stuff.
  3. Create a new static library for the os detection code. At first it should always report that it's unable to detect anything.
  4. The command line program should link in the library and use it to not do anything useful yet.
  5. Start adding actual detection capabilities to the library. At this point the command line program should be useful on at least one platform.
  6. Write a new test that runs the command line program and confirms the output.
  7. Add new detection and matching tests until we have "a bunch"
  8. Modify the condor_master to link this library and pass the information on. At this point the system is useful to local administrators.
  9. Modify the condor_collector to collect the information from many master ads and pass it on in the global ad. At this point the system is useful to Condor developers.
  10. while(there_are_undetected_platforms()) { add_more_detection_routines(); }
